references.paper_title: U-Net: Convolutional networks for biomedical image segmentation
references.reason: This foundational paper introduced the U-Net architecture, a highly influential model that has significantly impacted medical image segmentation and formed the basis of many subsequent architectures, including the one presented in this paper.

references.paper_title: nnU-Net: a self-configuring method for deep learning-based biomedical image segmentation
references.reason: This paper introduced nnU-Net, a highly successful and widely used medical image segmentation method that serves as a strong baseline and comparison point for many new methods in the field, including the one proposed in this paper.

references.paper_title: CoTr: Efficiently bridging CNN and transformer for 3D medical image segmentation
references.reason: This paper presented CoTr, a significant work that combines convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and transformers for 3D medical image segmentation, demonstrating the benefits of hybrid architectures and serving as a relevant comparison for the proposed method.

references.paper_title: DiNTS: Differentiable neural network topology search for 3D medical image segmentation
references.reason: This paper introduced DiNTS, a novel approach that utilizes neural architecture search (NAS) to optimize the architecture for 3D medical image segmentation, addressing the challenge of efficient architecture design which is also the focus of this paper.

references.paper_title: AMOS: A large-scale abdominal multi-organ benchmark for versatile medical image segmentation
references.reason: This paper introduced AMOS, a large-scale dataset specifically designed for abdominal multi-organ segmentation, providing a challenging benchmark used for evaluating and comparing the performance of various medical image segmentation methods, including the one presented in this paper.
